title: The UK’s ‘Astra Carta’ moment: Building a Space Sustainability Growth Platform
summary: The U.K. sees satellite servicing, debris removal and orbital sustainability as an opportunity to emerge as a major global space power.

title: NASA selects Falcon Heavy to launch Roman Space Telescope
summary: NASA has selected SpaceX to launch the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope on a Falcon Heavy, but at a price significantly higher than previous agency contracts.

title: SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket to launch NASA’s Roman Space Telescope
summary: NASA has chosen SpaceX’s Falcon Heavy rocket to launch its next major space telescope, a wide-field observatory that should directly complement the...

title: Boston Students to Hear from NASA, ESA Astronauts Aboard Space Station
summary: Massachusetts students will have an opportunity this week to hear from crew members aboard the International Space Station, including a NASA astronaut.

title: Oxford Space and SSTL unveil Wrapped Rib SAR antenna
summary: The United Kingdom’s Oxford Space Systems and Surrey Satellite Technology Ltd. completed construction of a deployable, Wrapped Rib antenna for small synthetic aperture radar satellites.

title: ESA funds Skimsat demonstrator study for VLEO
summary: The European Space Agency has awarded funds to develop a demonstrator for Skimsat, a small satellite platform designed to operate in very low Earth orbit (VLEO).

title: NASA Awards Launch Services Contract for Roman Space Telescope
summary: NASA has selected Space Exploration Technologies Corporation (SpaceX) in Hawthorne, California, to provide launch service for the Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope mission.

title: Microsoft reveals Azure Space Partner Community
summary: Microsoft is expanding its relationships with space companies through the Azure Space Partner Community, an initiative unveiled July 19 at the Microsoft Inspire 2022 conference.

title: Two companies join SpaceX in the race to Mars, with a launch possible in 2024
summary: "If it wasn't challenging, I wouldn't be doing it."

title: Relativity to launch Impulse Space’s Mars Lander as early as 2024
summary: Impulse Space has announced that the company will launch the first commercial payload to Mars on board Relativity Space’s Terran R rocket. Under the new partnership, Relativity will launch Impulse’s Mars Cruise Vehicle and Mars Lander from Cape Canaveral, Florida, as part of an exclusive agreement until 2029.
